In the spirit of accuracy (leaving out the political innuendo), the seal of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts does not nor ever did have the picture of an Indian with the words in a 'bubble' saying:  "Come over and Help Us".  That seal was used by the "Massachusetts Bay Colony".  It was used from 1629-1686 when it was 'annulled' and then again from 1689-1692.  So, yes it was used by the MBC, but has NOT been used for 324 years.  To quote John "... the Massachusetts seal WHICH FEATURES (which infers it is the current seal) an Indian saying:  "Come over and help us".  (emphasis added).  John, mispronouncing things is OK in this format, but not giving false/misleading information.

This video gets a lot right! In particular, good job of being explicit regarding the fact that Indigenous Americans weren't "primitive" or uncomplex human beings. However, the video also inadvertently perpetuates some misunderstandings and factual inaccuracies about Indigenous Americans (plus an incorrect historical date). 
1) First up, many Indigenous peoples have requested that people be as specific as possible and name their individual tribe(s) when referring to them so as to avoid confusion and dispel the myth that Native peoples aren't diverse. For instance, Debbie Reese (an educator who runs the awesome blog, American Indians in Children's Literature) is a Nambe Pueblo woman. If I didn't know that she's Nambe Pueblo, I'd say that she's Indigenous American or Indigenous or Native American or sometimes Native (always with a capital 'N'; "the natives" is disrespectful) - there's not a lot of consensus on which term is "correct" within the Indigenous community at large, but do avoid obviously outdated terms. It's best to avoid the term "Indian" because many Indigenous people find that term offensive due to its geographical and linguistic inaccuracy (depending on which origin of that term we're following). There are times when you describe conflicts or treaties involving "the Indians", which might cause confusion about which specific tribes you're referencing in which regions.
2) The visual representation of Pocahontas is stereotyped. In this video, Pocahontas looks more like a Plains Native person than like the Powhatan person she was. Getting appearances right individualizes and accurately places various Indigenous peoples so that non-Native audience members don't discount Indigenous peoples as a homogenized group. Historical and cultural accuracy is especially important in a video about history.
3) The first English settlement attempt wasn't in 1607. (However, that was the first British settlement attempt after Queen Elizabeth's death and the official govt unification of England and Scotland). Sir Walter Raleigh made two settlement attempts in 1584 and 1586 or 1587 (depending on sources). These settlements are also important to mark because they played important roles for Indigenous and English people alike. What we do and don't know about the Roanoke colony founded in 1586 says a lot about early Indigenous American/English relations. 
4) Pocahontas may never have participated in the infamous "saving John Smith's life" ceremony. John Smith wrote of several similar stories wherein girls or woman of stature made grand gestures to save his life. It's thought that he might've been capitalizing on stereotypes about people of color ("good savage" maiden vs. "bad savage" men) as well as playing in to his own self-importance in order to sell his sensational book account of his travels. However, it's true and sensitive to point out that if such a ceremony took place, it was very likely to demonstrate the Powhatans' authority over or to "adopt" Smith rather than being any actual threat on Smith's life.
Not that the video pushes the popular but false romantic tale, but for the record, Pocahontas and Smith were never romantically involved. She was a young girl at the time of the supposed life-saving incident. Years later when she saw Smith again in England, she was so upset to see him that she went off on her own for several hours. Another time, she accused him of lying. It's clear that Smith was someone who'd somehow wronged Pocahontas as opposed to being the hero figure that he made himself out to be.
5) It's questionable whether Smith at one point told the settlers to stop stealing food from the Powhatan people. However, Smith did demand food from the Powhatan people by threat of military force against them. Many Powhatan people were aware that the English posed a longterm threat long prior to the tensions that led to Opechancanough's leadership in organized acts of defense of Powhatan land rights. 
6) It's worth noting that according to the Mattaponi's history (the Mattaponi people have close ties with the Powhatan people), Pocahontas' son wasn't the child of John Rolfe, but the child of her first marriage to a Powhatan man. Pocahontas may have been coerced into marrying Rolfe after she was taken captive by the English. Rolfe was in the tobacco trade, among the first to exploit this plant that is sacred to so many tribes. The image that textbooks favor of Pocahontas being a kind of symbol for a happy-though-temporary unification of Indigenous and Anglo/European cultures is largely a myth, and understanding her real story is key in honestly portraying history.
7) Nathaniel Saltonstall's accounts of Native brutality against English settlers during the Pequot War are suspicious. In "Narratives of the Indian Wars, 1675-1699", Saltonstall is proved to be an unreliable narrator; in addition to some other confused remembrances on Saltonstall's part, it's at one point noted by the book's editor in regard to a letter detailing one Native/English conflict that, "The whole account is exaggerated," and is contradicted by a contemporary of Saltonstall's. It is entirely contrary to the traditional values of most Indigenous American societies to rape, to abuse animals, and to refuse quarter/not take captives. This is not to oversimplify Native peoples or to claim that they're incapable of touching on the dark side of humanity that lives in each of us. For instance, after the Battle of Little Big Horn in 1876, Lakota, Arapaho, and Cheyenne warriors were still so enraged by the United States military's recent massacres of Indigenous women, children, elders - everyone who was present at the Native camps that the Indigenous warriors decapitated the bodies of the dead White soldiers on the battlefield. However, it is true that throughout American history, Anglo/Europeans' accounts of Native peoples' violence against colonizers have often been exaggerated and sometimes outrightly fabricated. For example, with increased respect for Indigenous peoples' oral histories and new historical evidence, the practice of scalping is now widely believed to have been learned and used in retaliation by Native Americans only after Anglo/Europeans brought the practice to the Americas. At the very least, it should be said that Saltonstall's accounts are, if true, an example of Indigenous peoples equaling the instruction of inhumane acts first seen performed by Anglo/Europeans. On average, Indigenous Americans had harsher penalties against rape, strongly respected animals' welfare and opposed wasting any part of animal which could be used, thought of the mutilation of an enemy as dishonorable, and treated captives/prisoners of war better than Anglo/Europeans did.

5:54 The Pequot War was not about the English (British) vs the Pequots.  Historians know that this was a native war between the Pequot and the Mohegan/Narragansett tribes.  All of these tribes were fully immersed into trade between both Dutch and British traders at the time.  The Pequot were also instigators in the whole conflict.

However, the British that attacked the village killed the women, children and elderly in a semi-battle despite the villagers setting themselves on fire (according at least to William Bradford) and burning down their village with them inside.  Judging by what we know about the Pequot, they were a bit batshit insane.  Not saying they were completely wrong in their conflict with other tribes or the English (they were besties with the Dutch) but although the Mystic Massacre was horrible, it wasn't some uneven battle where the English slaughtered helpless natives.  (Please read the entire account by William Bradford that this video quoted from.)

Native Americans did sometimes trade land for goods, but only rarely.  More often, they were willing to give up rights to lands in exchange for better trading relationships and political alliances with the Europeans, which would in turn lead to a better trade of goods.  The best example of this is in Virginia, where Powhatan used the English basically as a tool in his own inter-tribal power plays, agreeing to leave Jamestown alone so he could use it goods and presence as 'allies' against others.

Native Americans were often fine about using or dealing in European currencies, at least after about 1570 or 1620.  This was because they knew that they could use European currency to obtain valuable and important trade goods -- tools, armor, drugs, weapons -- from the Europeans that would give them advantages over other Europeans later on and over other Native American groups they had ongoing rivalries with.
